description: From Middle French operation, from Old French operacion, from Latin operātiō, from the verb operor (“I work”), from opus, operis (“work”). Equivalent to operate +‎ -ion.

entries.meaning: The method by which a device performs its function.
examples: It is dangerous to look at the beam of a laser while it is in operation.

entries.meaning: The method or practice by which actions are done.
The act or process of operating; agency; the exertion of power, physical, mechanical, or moral.

examples: The police ran an operation to get vagrants off the streets.
The Katrina relief operation was considered botched.
We run our operation from a storefront.
They run a multinational produce-supply operation.
She had an operation to remove her appendix.

entries.meaning: English Wikipedia has an article on:Operation (mathematics)Wikipedia (computing, logic, mathematics) A procedure for generating a value from one or more other values (the operands);(mathematics, more formally) a function which maps zero or more (but typically two) operands to a single output value.
examples: The number of operands associated with an operation is called its arity; an operation of arity 2 is called a binary operation.

entries.meaning: (military) A military campaign (e.g. Operation Desert Storm)

examples: The bards  […]  had great operation on the vulgar.
